title: Senator Kavanagh's Carpet Recycling Bill Signed Into Law - The New York State Senate
summary: New York State passed a Carpet EPR bill requiring carpet manufacturers to establish a program for recycling discarded carpet, setting recycling performance goals and prohibiting hazardous chemicals in carpets from 2026 onwards.
green_innovation: TRUE - This initiative aligns with environmental sustainability goals by reducing waste, promoting circular economy principles, and protecting human health and the environment through extended producer responsibility for carpet recycling.
business_innovation: FALSE - The focus of the article is on environmental regulations and recycling programs rather than a new or improved product or business process being introduced on the market.
green_product: TRUE - The article discusses the implementation of a program to recycle discarded carpet, which aligns with the definition of a green product by significantly reducing its environmental impact throughout its life cycle.
green_process: TRUE - The implementation of carpet recycling programs and performance goals in the article signifies a green process that minimizes environmental impacts in the manufacturing and disposal of carpets.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 561720 - Janitorial Services, 562920 - Materials Recovery Facilities, 562998 - All Other Miscellaneous Waste Management Services, 325211 - Plastics Material and Resin Manufacturing
greenwashing: FALSE - The article does not exhibit signs of greenwashing, as it focuses on genuine efforts to improve recycling practices and reduce harmful substances in carpets, backed by legislative actions and environmental advocacy.

title: Hundreds of undersized lobsters found in New York City supermarkets - SeafoodSource
summary: The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation found hundreds of undersized lobsters for sale in New York City supermarkets, leading to violation notices and fines, with the lobsters being confiscated and donated to a food pantry.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 445220 - Fish and Seafood Markets, 722110 - Full-Service Restaurants, 424460 - Fish and Seafood Merchant Wholesalers, 445230 - Fruit and Vegetable Markets

title: The 'Shellmet' Is an Eco-Friendly Solution to Marine Waste in Japan | LBBOnline - Little Black Book
summary: TBWA\HAKUHODO and Koushi Chemical Industry Co. introduced 'Shellmet', an eco-friendly helmet made from wasted scallop shells, aiming to tackle the issue of surplus shells in Sarufutsu Village, Hokkaido. The Shellmet is a disaster prevention helmet made from a new material based on scallop shells and recycled plastic, contributing to reduced CO2 emissions and waste. It incorporates a biomimicry design inspired by scallop shells, offering durability and sustainability. A crowdfunding campaign will support the product's promotion and adoption in the village and beyond.
company: TBWA\HAKUHODO and Koushi Chemical Industry Co.

title: Implementing circular economy and sustainability policies in Rwanda: Experiences of Rwandan manufacturers with the ... - Frontiers
summary: The article discusses Rwanda's sustainability policies, experiences of manufacturers post implementation of the plastic ban, and challenges faced in transitioning to alternative materials. It explores the alignment of Rwanda's sustainability policies with circular economy principles and the importance of government support in facilitating the transition to more sustainable practices.

title: Flipkart Launches ‘Flipkart Green’ for Customers Looking to Adopt a Sustainable Lifestyle - Indian Retailer
summary: The article discusses the 'Scars are Beautiful' campaign by Juicy Chemistry and Mommy Shots by Amrita, celebrating the beauty of postpartum bodies and stretch marks and empowering women to embrace their unique motherhood journeys.
